title: Organizations are pushing AI adoption harder than ever‚Ä¶ yet 48.8% of employees hide their AI use to avoid judgment.
description:
Organizations are pushing AI adoption harder than ever‚Ä¶ yet 48.8% of employees hide their AI use to avoid judgment. Even worse? 53.4% of C-suite executives are doing the same.

And the funny part? These same companies are building AI enablement teams to "drive adoption".

Does that make sense to you? Because clearly, I'm missing something.

I've been speaking with individuals across organizations, and here's what's happening‚Ä¶

1Ô∏è‚É£ Leadership declares "AI is critical for our future"

2Ô∏è‚É£ They form an "AI enablement team" that meets regularly with identified "AI leads" across organizational functions

3Ô∏è‚É£ They meet regularly‚Ä¶ ask the leads about possible use cases and share parlor tricks like email summaries and basic note comparisons to drive use of the corporate "chatbot"

That's it. That's the playbook.

Here's the problem. Email, document review... those aren't the game-changing tasks that make a difference, like:

üëâ Helping finance teams more efficiently categorize expenses

üëâ Assisting marketing tap into customer data for personalized campaigns at scale

üëâ Using firm legal standards to shorten contract review cycles


The enablement team can't help, not because they don't want to, but because the valuable use cases that teams actually need, while not making leadership's top 2-3 priorities, are far more complex to implement than a simple LLM driven "chatbot". 

They require control of ecosystems and authority to drive change that these teams simply aren‚Äôt given responsibility for.

So what happens?

Employees think everyone else has figured out the "real" AI while they're stuck drafting basic documents with ‚ÄúChatGPT‚Äù. 

The shame isn't in using AI‚Ä¶ it's in how embarrassingly simple the tasks are they're using it for.

A new survey blames this widespread AI shame on lack of training, guidance, and policies.

But, they've got it backwards.

Training and guidance aren't the problem. Capability is.

What real AI enablement looks like:

‚úîÔ∏è Understand business problems, not just tech features (and not just the high ROI challenges) 
‚úîÔ∏è Document actual workflows, and the "activities" AI can help before recommending tools 
‚úîÔ∏è Create safe environments for experimentation and failure of those activities 
‚úîÔ∏è Provide hands-on implementation guidance, with governance support
‚úîÔ∏è Have authority to help drive change, not just suggest tools and generic uses 
‚úîÔ∏è Elevate successful use cases to program or enterprise level

This isn't about AI expertise. It's about AI enablement teams with the authority and the control of an ecosystem to drive actual transformation... not just evangelizing.

So tell me, does your current AI adoption approach make sense? Let me know. | 16 comments on LinkedIn

comment.text: You make much sense, Darlene Newman. The problem is not with the technology, but with the lack of a proper strategy. Companies give people tools without giving them the authority to drive meaningful change. Without that authority, teams cannot truly optimize business processes.

Spot on. FIs will site risk as the key rationale for ‚Äúproceeding with caution‚Äù on meaningful use cases but it goes deeper. There is a real palpable fear of what this new world will look like for employees, leadership, various stakeholders... The fear may be valid but that is exactly the reason why organizations must face it head on. Resistance is futile.
Employees hiding AI use isn‚Äôt a culture problem, it‚Äôs a reflection of limited scope and support. Darlene Newman
True transformation comes from solving meaningful business problems, not just automating minor tasks. Darlene Newman

‚ÄúSpot on. Most AI enablement programs stop at evangelizing instead of empowering. Without authority to rewire workflows and drive real change, teams are left tinkering with chatbots while the real opportunities go untouched. Transformation requires control of ecosystems, not just toolkits.‚Äù
Too much focus on simply utilizing AI and not enough focus on strategies, efficiencies, reworking processes.
Totally agree. Most orgs confuse AI adoption with AI usage. Until enablement teams are empowered to tackle core processes, employees will keep treating it like a parlor trick. Darlene Newman
